------=_NextPart_000_0000_01C0F296.7497DE60
Content-Type: text/plain;

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

A perspective that has worked well for me is that protected methods are
private to the framework but not within it. So you set a method as protected
if it is not part of the public interface that the framework provides but it
does provide services to other classes within the framework or to extensions
to the framework (i.e. subclasses).

So if you are testing a framework as a 'black box' service provider, you
don't necessarily need to test protected methods, but if you are testing a
framework at a deeper level, then you might find yourself doing just that.

  -----Original Message-----
  From: Yishay Mor [mailto:ymor@...]
  Sent: Monday, June 11, 2001 4:39 PM
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?


  my 2c -
  When teaching Java, I used to quote the SUN text book: "if your code has a
lot of protected methods, it is either very badly or very elegantly
designed".



        > Also, I take the term "public interface" as relative. If an object
    exposes an interface (set of methods)
        > to its peer objects within its package, I see no reason not to
test
    it, even though those methods are
        > package-protected.

    I guess I disagree here.  I am not convinced that package-potected
methods
    are part of a public interface.  If they are used that way I would
question
    whether some refactoring needed to take place.  But that's just my
opinion.
    I don't want to seem like I am picking on your design decisions.
